item.title: Week 1
item.description:
Week 1 OOP

2 - 4 Hours

Assignment

  • Open a Github Account with your university email. If you already have one please add the university email.
  • Request the Github Student Developer Pack
  • Clone our course Github Repository and follow the instructions there

Optional

It is better if you use Linux OS instead of Windows OS during this course. If you know how to do it attempt to have both installed on your computer. You could also boot linux from a USB or CD following this instructions

Learn

Below a video with some basics about command line.

Here some command lines software that runs on your browser. No install needed

  • https://webvm.io/

Below some short tutorial that you may find useful. And you have a no-install terminal to try it!

Here it is a longer one if you want more info. It even has more visits!

A cheat sheet for command line

Quiz

Here is a very nice webpage to test your knowledge with simple questions

  • https://cmdchallenge.com/

item.title: Week 2
item.description:
Week 2: Intro to Healthcare

2 - 4 Hours

Class Content

During class we will see the Journey of a patient through the healthcare system and the different systems in place that assist him and the healthcare providers through the journey of accessing and delivering care.

Assignment

  • Open a Github Account with your university email. If you already have one please add the university email.
  • Request the Github Student Developer Pack
  • Request access to MIMIC III, MIMIC IV and the MIMIC IV demo in the OMOP-CDM format and the MIMIC III demo
  • Watch all the videos and Read all the articles with links at the bottom of this webpage

Learn

A short explanation of US Healthcare and Canadian Healthcare

Colombian Healthcare System

Readings

I suggest you read this material before our class

  • Digital health ecosystems: A payer perspective
  • Digital transformation From a buzzword to an imperative for health systems

Optional

  • Foundation of AI in Healthcare and MedTech with Jonathan Chen, MD, PhD, Stanford

item.title: Week 2
item.description:
Systems Engineering and its Applications

15 mins

Class Content

Here the link for our class slides. To access it you need to login with your University Google account.

Learn

Below a video that explains what is a Full Stack Developer in the context of web development.

Brief Quiz

What are the two roles a Full Stack developer should do?

  • Frontend Developer
  • Backend Developer

Which Two languages are part of frontend development?

  • HTML
  • Java Script

Which Two languages are part of backend development?

  • Ruby
  • Python

item.title: Week 2
item.description:
Week 2: Classes and Objects

4 - 6 Hours

Class content

  • Here the link for the slides we used in class

Assignment

  • This week your main assignment will be to follow the instructions in this section of our Github Repo.
  • You should also check the tutorial below and get some Python knowledge

Optional

Below some resources to improve your teamwork

Basic Intro to Python

Quiz

What are the key features of Python?

  • Python is an interpreted language
  • Python is dynamically typed

Are Python Lists Mutable?

  • Yes

Are Python Tuples Mutable?

  • No

If I have this list a = [2, 4, 8, 10, 3, 2] and write this slice a[1:3] what is the result?

  • [4, 8]

Questions taken and modified from here

item.title: Week 3
item.description:
Week 3: Clinical Data and Standardization

2 - 4 Hours

Class Content

During class we will see the need for Interoperability. We will see the differences between basic interoperability (scheme, messages, etc…) and semantic interoperability. The we will zoom in into the different information systems a hospital may have (LIMS, PCAS, Waveforms, Appointments, etc…) and how they can communicate between them and with another healthcare institution. After that we will briefly touch upon HL7 V2 and FHIR to explain the needs of Controlled terminologies/vocabularies and Ontologies. We will zoom in into ICD-10 and SNOMED-CT and explain the differences between them.

Assignment

  • Read everything from the Readings section
  • Follow the instructions to setup our development environment. The instructions are available on our course Github repo.
  • Open an Azure for Students account with your University email. This account and the credits given does nto require you to provide a credit card.
  • Open a Google Cloud account with your university email. This one may require you to have a credit card.
  • Watch (and hopefully follow) the short R tutorial

Readings

  • Andrew Ng Launches A Campaign For Data-Centric AI
  • How data standardization can improve patient outcomes -La agenda de Salud Digital para generar interoperabilidad -Así funcionará la historia clínica electrónica en Colombia

Learn

A short tutorial on R

item.title: Week 3
item.description:
Intro to Google Colab and Python

mins

Class Content

Here the link to the Jupyter Notebook we showed on Google Colab

Learn

Below a short introductory video on Google Colab

Brief Quiz

Where is the Jupyter Notebook running when you execute the cells inside a Google Colab

  • On a Virtual Machine on the Cloud

item.title: Week 3
item.description:
Week 3: Relationships between classes and Encapsulation

2 - 3 Hours

Class content

  • Encapsulation and composition class slides here

Assignments

  • Read the Plant UML language specification for a Class Diagram
  • Run the Plant UML code generated in our last class but inside VS code. Instructions in how to do that can be found here
  • Search on the web for a real case us of UML to specify a class diagram for a Python application. It does not need to be complicated and it is ok if you do not understand everything that is going on.

Learn

Few videos with nice short tutorials to create Class Diagrams with Plant UML. The last one is using Lucid Chart but it is a nice video for UML for class diagrams

item.title: Week 4
item.description:
Week 4: Clinical Data and Standardization

2 - 4 Hours

Class Content

In this class we will explain in more detail the role of ontologies in the content of standardizing data elements from EHR and claims data. We will zoom in into the OMOP-CDM data model and the need of an ETL from source data to this model.

Assignments

  • Last week there was a bug in the page and the assignments were not there. Please take a look at week 3 assignments and be sure you have done all of them.
  • Open an account on Athena with your university email and navigate the interface to become familiar with it.
  • Create an HL7 V2 message with a piece of your information a of course some fake one.
  • Finish all the steps to access MIMIC III and MIMIC IV data.
  • Follow the instructions on this Github Repository. We will use this repo the entire semester

In-Class Activity

  • Given the class size we will divide in four groups each group will have a different but related assignment. By the end of the class it is expected that all the code will be pushed to a single GitHub repository
    • Group 1: Download the MIMIC IV OMOP-CDM demo dataset and load it into a SQL Lite Database using RSQLite
    • Group 2: Download the MIMIC IV OMOP-CDM demo dataset and produce a graph like the one below for conditions and procedures
    • Group 3: Download the MIMIC IV OMOP-CDM demo dataset and produce a graph like the one below for drugs and measurements
    • Group 4: Run the OHDSI Data Quality Dashboard to Visualize the file(results_MIMICIVdemo210426.json) generated when running the tool on the demo data. The file is part of the MIMIC IV OMOP-CDM demo dataset

Example of graph to be generated for Groups 2 and 3

Readings

  • Read sections 4 and 4.1 of the OHDSI book

Learn

The EHDEN academy is an excellent resource to expand your knowledge on the OMOP-CDM. Please check it out and hopefully you peek into some videos for courses like the OMOP-CDM and Standardized vocabularies.

A short video about Lessons Learned Converting Patient-Level Data to the OMOP Common Data Model to Support the COVID-19 Crisis

item.title: Week 4
item.description:
List, Dictionaries and Tuples in Python

45 mins

Class Content

During class we will cover the basics of Lists, dictionaries and tuples in Python and some fun exercises with them.

  • Google Colab Jupyter Notebook

Learn

Below a short video if you want to start learning some of the content before class and come with awesome questions.

Brief Quiz

Can I change the contents of a tuple once created?

  • Once created you cannot change the contents of a tuple. This characteristic is called immutable.

item.title: Week 5
item.description:
Week 5: Analytical Use cases with Clinical Data

2 - 4 Hours

Class Content

  • In this class we will cover in detail the main possible analytical use cases we can have when dealing with EHR data. The three main analyses we will cover will be:
    • Characterization
    • Population-level Estimation
    • Patient-level Prediction
  • Here you will find instructions to setup a VM in Microsoft Azure that runs the Docker image with all the OHDSI environment already setup

Assignments

  • Watch the short video with a small introduction to SQL
  • Read all the mandatory readings

In-class Activity

During class we will discuss ideas for the final project and submit a 500 word summary at the end of it using this Google form

Readings

  • Mandatory Readings
    • Read chapter 7 of the OHDSI book.
  • Go to Week 6 section and start the mandatory readings there so you have time to finish them by the class on Week 6

Learn

CHARYBDIS Presentation (Kristin Kostka, 2/23/21 OHDSI Community Call)

The video describes a large scale observational study whose results can be visualized here

A short introduction to SQL

item.title: Week 6
item.description:
Week 6: Data Processing and Feature generation with clinical data

2 - 4 Hours

Class Content

In this class we will start describing the methods used to process EHR data and generate features with it.

Assignments

  • Read all the mandatory readings
  • Contribute to our Github repository by taking the code generated in week 4 class activity and merging everything in a single .Rmd in our class repo. For doing that your first need to fork and then perform a pull request. The route for the file we will be editing together is bioinf_202210/src/assigment1.Rmd

Readings

  • Mandatory Readings
    • Get acquainted with the Feature Extraction OHDSI package. You just need to read and if you wish you could follow along some of the examples using the sample Eunomia Dataset.
      • Here is the portion of the documentation that describes how the features are generated
      • Here is the pre-specified analyses CSV. The SQL files mentioned there are very hard to read because they are supporting a wide range of use cases.
    • Read the articles:
      • Population-Level Prediction of Type 2 Diabetes From Claims Data and Analysis of Risk Factors
        • GitHub Repository
      • Democratizing EHR analyses with FIDDLE: a flexible data-driven preprocessing pipeline for structured clinical data
        • GitHub Repository

Note: If you do not understand everything is ok. We will discuss the packages and papers during class

Learn

item.title: Week 4
item.description:
Week 4: Python Refresher and Basic Inheritance

1 - 2 Hours

Class content

  • Slides
    • Case Study: Iris Dataset Classification Problem
    • Basic Inheritance

Assignments

  • Run inside the dev container and/or the virtual machine on Azure within VS Code
    • concept_image.py
    • distance_images.py
  • Bring an idea for the project you want to work on. We will discuss your idea during regular class time on Thursday

Learn

Here a link with a description about the Jupyter cells that we are using in the code you need to run as assignment this week. Is a slightly different way to run a jupyter notebook using an interactive window.

Below a short video that have a brief explanation about this feature in VS code

item.title: Week 5
item.description:
Dataframes part 1: Open data by MinTIC + Pandas + Variables types

2 - 3 Hours

Class Content

  • Google Colab Jupyter Notebook
  • Colombian Government Open Data webpage
    • Application Programming Interface (API) for Colombian Government Open Data: SODA

Assignments

  • Create a Python list with heights and names.

Activity 1

  • Here the link to upload your work the first Activity. Due date and all the details are in this Google Colab. Be sure to make a copy of it. If you do not have your own copy you cannot edit. To access it you need to be logged in with your university email

Learn

Below a nice Introductory tutorial on Pandas Dataframes

NOTE If you watch this before our class it will be an even better time together.

Brief Quiz

What is a famous software that stores data in a similar way than Dataframes?

  • Microsoft Excel
  • Google Spreadsheets

Why Dataframes are so popular?

  • Because they allow you to manipulate, transform and visualize data very easily in a programmatic and repeatable way.

item.title: Week 5
item.description:
Week 5: Objects in Python - Basic Inheritance and Polymorphism

2 - 3 Hours

Class content

  • Basic inheritance and polymorphism
    • Class activity: Present the concepts to your classmates in groups. Then one of the members of the group present the concept to the entire course. This activity encourages self-learning and concept reinforcement by teaching what was learned.
  • Objects in Python: The code is now in our repo on oop_202201/chapters/ch_02/src/

Assignments

  • Read:
    • Read pages 21 to 34 of the Book Python Object-Oriented Programming: Build robust and maintainable object-oriented Python applications and libraries. Remember that this is our textbook and we will be using it extensively during our semester.
    • Read about MRO: Method Resolution Order in Python
    • Read about polymorphism and its specifics within Python.
  • Write:
    • Write a short project description. The description should be about 500 words. The description should be in English.
      • Google form link

Note It is important you remember that is is ok if you do not understand everything you are assigned to read. The important part is that you actually read. Please bring the questions you may have regarding the material to our class.

Learn

  • Short blog posts explaining:
    • MRO
    • Polymorphism
  • Nice intro Python course if you still need some help to acquaint yourselves with it

NOTE: Sorry no videos this week on the learn section

item.title: Week 6
item.description:
Lab Visit

2 - 3 Hours

Class Content

  • Visit to Department lab
  • Deadline for Activity 1

Assignments

  • Select a plot from this gallery and reproduce it on a Google Colab. Change at least one aspect of the plot.

Learn

Below a nice Introductory tutorial of Seaborn

Brief Quiz

What are two types of plots you can do on Seaborn that are particularly beautiful when compared with Matplotlib?

  • Scatterplots
  • Density plots

item.title: Week 6
item.description:
Week 6: Objects in Python - Exception management, class properties and decorators in Python

2 - 3 Hours

Class content

  • Practical Class: We will continue covering objects in python and its implementation details. We will implement portions of our case study.
  • Theoretical Class:
    • Exception management
    • Properties and decorators

In-class activity

  • Co-evaluation form of project abstracts. Please fill the form in this link. You will see all the proposals from your classmates even in the other course section.

Assignments

  • Read about super in Python
  • Read PEP 8 Style Guide for Python Code. I expect you to finish this reading on week 7.
  • Create 3 or more simple classes with Python MRO is needed. Then use a wrapper to solve the issue.
  • Watch the two videos below. Those videos will help you understand the difference between functional and non-functional requirements.
  • Solutions to your final project: You need to find and summarize the following in maximum 2 pages
    • Functional and non-functional requirements.
    • Similar solutions in the literature and the market
    • List of possible solutions to the problem *type of application, type of interaction, etc…)
    • Available technologies for the implementation of solutions
  • Please create a Google Doc and share the link on this form

Learn

item.title: Week 7
item.description:
Dataframes part 2: Pandas + Matplotlib + Seaborn

1 - 2 Hours

Class Content

  • Google Colab Jupyter Notebook
  • Matplotlib Webpage
  • Seaborn Webpage

Learn

  • Below a short video with an explanation of how to mount GDrive on Google Colab
  • Short video to refresh your knowledge on slicing with pandas

Brief Quiz

What is the benefit of mounting GDrive on Google Colab?

  • It provides easier and faster access to the files stored on GDrive

item.title: Week 8
item.description:
Seaborn and Aggregation Functions part 1: One Level Aggregation

2 - 3 Hours

Class Content

  • Google Colab Jupyter Notebook
  • Pandas group by function

Assignments

  • You need to think in a data science project you would like to do. After that you need to write a 500 words summary and submit that by Tuesday April 5th on this link

Learn

Below a nice video explaining the pandas group by function

Brief Quiz

When should I use the group by function?

item.title: Jian Yang and Monica Hall Win the Best Paper Award at Wowchemy 2020
item.description:
Congratulations to Jian Yang and Monica Hall for winning the Best Paper Award at the 2020 Conference on Wowchemy for their paper “Learning Wowchemy”.
